node_2: dc comics character barry allen / flash
edge: The Flash is a superhero based on the DC Comics character Barry Allen.
The Flash is the superhero alter ego of Barry Allen in the DC Comics.
The Flash is a part of the DC Extended Universe, which includes multiple films based on DC Comics characters.
Ezra Miller portrays Barry Allen in the film adaptation of The Flash.
Sasha Calle plays Supergirl in the film adaptation of The Flash.
The film adaptation of The Flash is inspired by the comic book storyline Flashpoint (2011).
Michael Keaton reprises his role as Batman from the films Batman (1989) and Batman Returns (1992) in the film adaptation of The Flash.
The film adaptation of The Flash features multiple versions of Batman, including Michael Keaton's portrayal from the films Batman (1989) and Batman Returns (1992).
The Flash premiered at Grauman's Chinese Theatre in Hollywood, Los Angeles.
Warner Bros. Pictures released The Flash in the United States on June 16, following multiple delays caused by director changes and the COVID-19 pandemic.
The Flash received mixed reviews from critics.
Despite grossing $271.3 million worldwide, The Flash was still considered a box-office bomb due to its high production budget.
The release of The Flash was delayed several times due to director changes, which included Rick Famuyiwa and Dope director Phil Lord and Christopher Miller.
The release of The Flash was also delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Grauman's Chinese Theatre is located in Hollywood, Los Angeles.
The release of The Flash was also affected by director Rick Miller's legal issues and controversies.
The release of The Flash was also impacted by the DC Universe, which is in the process of being rebooted.
The mixed reception and box-office performance of The Flash were also attributed to a decline in the popularity of the superhero genre.
Some critics also criticized the film's marketing practices, which they felt did not accurately represent the final product.

The Flash is a part of the Justice League, which includes Superman, Batman, Wonder Woman, and others, as depicted in 'Justice League: Mortal'. Adam Brody was cast to play The Flash in this film, which was intended to be the start of a franchise with planned sequels and spin-offs.
Warner Bros. Pictures hired David S. Goyer to write, direct, and produce a new version of The Flash in December 2004.
Development on a film based on the DC Comics character the Flash began in the late 1980s when Warner Bros. Pictures hired comic book writer Jeph Loeb to write a screenplay.
Ryan Reynolds was approached by David S. Goyer to portray Wally West / The Flash in the film, after working with him on the Marvel Comics–based film Blade: Trinity (2004).
David S. Goyer was influenced for the film's tone by the Flash comic book runs by Mike Baron, Mark Waid, and Geoff Johns.
In September, George Miller signed on to direct the film titled 'Justice League: Mortal', with Michelle and Kieran Mulroney writing the screenplay.

The DCEU is an interconnected narrative continuity shared by superhero films produced by DC Films and distributed by Warner Bros. Pictures.

The release date of The Flash was moved to June 23, 2023, in March 2022 to provide more time for visual effects work to be completed.
The impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the workload of visual effects vendors led Warner Bros. To adjust its release schedule, with The Flash being moved to June 23, 2023.

In April 2022, the final writing credits for The Flash were revealed: Hodson received screenplay credit; Daley, Goldstein, and Harold received screen story credit; and off-screen credit for additional writing material went to Rebecca Drysdale, Famuyiwa, Grahame-Smith, Johns, Lord, Christopher Miller, Ezra Miller, Morrison, and Adam Sztykiel.

In May 2022, it was revealed that Adam Sztykiel, who had previously collaborated with Miller on the screenplay for 'How to Be Single', would also be involved in the scriptwriting process for The Flash. This suggests a possible collaboration and relationship between 'The Flash' and 'Adam Sztykiel' through Miller.

The poor box-office opening of 'The Flash' has been attributed to the phenomenon of superhero fatigue, which refers to audience exhaustion with the oversaturation of superhero movies in recent years.
Following the release of 'The Flash', there were mixed reviews from critics and audiences, leading to less-than-expected box office returns.

The film's opening weekend was also impacted by the controversy surrounding its lead actor Ezra Miller, who has been involved in several legal issues and has faced criticism from some segments of society.

Another superhero movie, 'Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse', was also released around the same time as 'The Flash', leading to increased competition and potentially lower box office returns for both films.
Following the poor performance of 'The Flash' and other recent DC movies, there have been rumors that Warner Bros. May be planning a complete reboot of the DC Universe.

The statement 'which could have provided some padding from what was expected to be a steep box-office decline from its opening weekend' indicates that the concept 'Steep box-office decline' is related to the concept 'Expected'. This relation can be interpreted as a cause-effect relationship where the steep box-office decline might have been avoided if it were expected.

The second and third weekends of the superhero film witnessed a steep drop in box office collection. The statement 'which could have provided some padding from what was expected to be a steep box-office decline from its opening weekend' further elaborates this relation.
